FacilityName: Henderson Cold Storage, Inc.dba P&O Cold Logistics

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Henderson Cold Storage employs two independent refrigeration systems for cooler and freezer storage.  Henderson Cold Storage?s senior management is not only committed to offer a superior service but to also maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  Henderson Cold Storage?s safety and environmental policies are administered by the Chief Engineer.  These programs include forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturers documentation, Emergency Response Plan, as well as the Risk Management Plan.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Henderson Cold Storage facility is located at 830 E Horizon Drive in Henderson, Nevada.   With the exception of the Condensers and the Phase I/II High Pressure Receiver, all of the ammonia equipment is located inside.  The facility consists of two buildings: Phase I/II was constructed in 1988 and Phase III was constructed in 1999.  An expansion of Phase I/II was completed in 1994.

The primary business of Henderson Cold Storage is to provide cooler and freezer warehousing space.  In order to conduct operations, the facility maintains two refrigeration systems, one in each of the Phase I/II buildings and the Phase III buildings.  The Phase I/II and Phase III refrigeration systems contain approximately 7,300 and 16,160 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, respectively.  Each refrigeration system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for the warehouse evaporators.  Typical operating conditions range from 1.6'' Hg on the low pressure side of the system to 160 psig on the high side of the system.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

In order to operate the ammonia refrigeration system, the facility complies with the following risk management regulations:

1) OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM);
2) EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP); and
3) NDEP's Chemical Accident Prevention Program (CAPP).

These regulations impose numerous requirements on the facility to ensure the safety of the public and on-site workers.  The following summarizes the key compliance programs that have been implemented by Henderson Cold Storage to prevent the accidental release of ammonia from the facility.  The Operating Procedures program ensures that the ammonia systems are operated in a safe manner.  The Training program ensures that personnel fully understand how to perform their jobs in a safe manner.  The Mechanical Integrity program ensures that the ammonia systems are in proper working condition based upon routine testing, inspections, and maintenance according to manufacturer's specifications and industry standards.  The Management of Change program ensures that process modifications are implemented in a safe manner.  The Pre-Startup Safety Review program ensures that adequate safety measures are in place before ammonia is introduced into a process.  The Hot Work Permit program ensures that Henderson Cold Storage's employees and contractors perform hot work (e.g. welding) in a safe manner.  The Contractor Safety program ensures that contractors understand the hazards of ammonia and must take specified precautions to safely complete job requirements.

It is important to note that the refrigeration systems have been designed with several safety features to prevent the accidental release of ammonia.  For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits and there are ammonia sensors located throughout the facility which will shutdown

the refrigeration system in the event of detection of a release.  Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.  Operators perform inspections of each engine room and record typical operating parameters at least once daily.  Additionally, critical process parameters are continuously monitored by an external alarm company which will alert operators in the event an abnormal situation arises.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Based upon the Henderson Cold Storage Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation (09/21/2004), there have not been any reportable releases of ammonia at the facility over the past five years (September 1999 - September 2004).

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility has an Emergency Response Plan (plan) in effect at the facility.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:  

? save lives;
? minimize and avoid injuries;
? protect the environment; and
? minimize property damage.

The Plan provides the notification procedures and evacuation routes for emergencies that may arise at the facility as well as detailing the training, procedures, and members of the Emergency Response Team.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations.  Facility personnel receive annual training regarding the emergency procedures and the Emergency Response Team holds regular drills.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

In 1997 and 1999 respectively, the Phase I/II and Phase III refrigeration systems were thoroughly examined for safety hazards by way of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).  In addition, a Revalidation of the initial Process Hazard Analysis Studies was performed in September 2004.  The 2004 PHA Revalidation consisted of:

? a detailed review of the scenarios of concern in the HAZOP logtables from the previous studies;
? a series of safety checklists;
? a review of

the status of recommendations from the initial studies; and
? a facility inspection.

The mitigation measures include modification to the existing policies and procedures in place at the facility in an effort to enhance the safety and operability of the refrigeration system.  All recommendations resulting from the revalidation study are due to be completed by October 2005.
